What we'll discuss

It's a Matryoshka Doll

  • Your App

Your App

The simplest way for you to get code that works on more than your machine alone, is to abstract away the hardware.

Docker Containers

They act as an extraction between the application and the server

  • You get a stripped down operating system
  • You install any extras you need
  • You run your app

Docker Compose

A way to work with multiple docker containers on one machine

  • Allows you to set up containers that need to interact to provide a service
  • Allows containers to talk to each other by setting up interconnected ports
  • Lets you describe what you want, rather than how to make what you want.
    • Easier to reason about
    • Easier to replicate

Kubernetes

A way to work with multiple docker containers on multiple machines

  • More resilient to errors
  • Platform agnostic
  • Allows a user to take their setup and move to a different provider
  • Can be run locally, on premises or on a cloud provider

Pod

Your container, with some extra metadata. Kubernetes uses this metadata to keep your app stable.

  • Pods are created to meet demand of your app
  • Pods are killed when there is a fault with a container.
  • Treat as ephemeral
  • You can have more than one container to a pod, just be aware that anything in a pod will scale together.
  • Pods will only be available when all containers inside them are marked as healthy

Service

How you connect to containers in a stable manner.

  • They provide a name and ip address which will never change
  • They will keep a list of the relevant pods, and will direct traffic to pods when they are healthy.
  • If a pod reports as unhealthy, they are removed from the list and an identical pod is created.

Deployments

Help you make rolling deployments, where pods are replaced one by one. Treats rollbacks in the same manner.
